title: 112_hr4259
content: The Act titled "End Trafficking in Government Contracting Act of 2012" defines key terms like executive agency, subcontractor, subgrantee, and United States. It also outlines contracting requirements. Section 106(g) of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 is amended to allow remedial actions under the End Trafficking in Government Contracting Act of 2012 for engaging in trafficking, forced labor, or supporting trafficking activities. The End Trafficking in Government Contracting Act of 2012 prohibits actions such as destroying, concealing, or confiscating an employee's immigration documents without consent, failing to repatriate an employee, and soliciting employment through false pretenses. The End Trafficking in Government Contracting Act of 2012 prohibits actions such as charging exorbitant placement fees, violating recruitment laws, and providing inhumane living conditions for recruited employees. SEC. 4. COMPLIANCE PLAN AND CERTIFICATION REQUIREMENT. The head of an executive agency must not provide grants or contracts over $1,000,000 for overseas performance without certification that the recipient complies with the Trafficking Victims Protection Act and has procedures in place to prevent trafficking activities. The recipient must detect and terminate any subcontractor or employee engaged in prohibited activities. Plans must be appropriate to the grant's size and complexity, and the recipient must disclose the plan to the contracting officer upon request. The recipient must disclose the plan to the contracting officer upon request and post relevant contents on its website and workplace. Contracts performed predominantly overseas if services outside the US exceed $500,000. SEC. 5. MONITORING AND INVESTIGATION OF TRAFFICKING IN PERSONS. Investigation process initiated upon receipt of credible evidence of trafficking activity by recipient, subgrantee, subcontractor, or agent. Request for immediate investigation by Office of Inspector General before grant or contract renewal. Upon receipt of credible evidence of trafficking activity, the agency's Office of Inspector General or another investigative unit shall conduct an investigation and submit a report to the contracting officer. Section 106(g) of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act allows for remedial actions if a recipient of a grant or contract engages in trafficking activities. Remedial actions may include removing employees, terminating subcontracts, or suspending payments. The Trafficking Victims Protection Act allows for remedial actions if a recipient of a grant or contract engages in trafficking activities. Remedial actions may include withholding award fees, declining contract options, terminating the contract, referring the matter for suspension or debarment, or prosecution under applicable law. This subsection does not limit the scope of applicable remedies. The contracting or grant official may consider a contractor or grantee's compliance with a plan under section 4 as a mitigating factor in determining applicable remedies. Relevant findings from a report must be included in the Federal Awardee Performance and Integrity Information System (FAPIIS) for future contract considerations. The head of an executive agency must ensure that recipients of grants, contracts, or cooperative agreements report any credible evidence of trafficking in persons to the Inspector General and cooperate with federal agencies for audits and investigations. SEC. 7. Expansion of fraud in foreign labor contracting to include work outside the United States. Section 1351 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include provisions for work outside the United States, targeting individuals who knowingly recruit, solicit, or hire persons for work on U.S. Government contracts or military installations abroad through fraudulent means. Penalties include fines or imprisonment for up to 5 years. SEC. 8. IMPROVING DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE ACCOUNTABILITY FOR REPORTING TRAFFICKING IN PERSONS CLAIMS AND VIOLATIONS. Section 105(d)(7)(H) of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include reporting of trafficking in persons cases to the Under Secretary of Defense for Personnel and Readiness, as well as trafficking in persons activities of contractors to the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, Technology, and Logistics. SEC. 9. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not override or change the legal responsibilities of parties under the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000.
